page.title: 06 WATER FOR LEWES
page.content: The{river Ouse}is tidal at Lewes, flowing between earth banks raised to prevent{flooding.}Its tributaries have sluices to prevent tidal flow:the Cockshut, the Winterbourne and the Glynde Reach. The Winterbourne flows mostly on porous chalk and dries up from April to December.It last flooded in l974, inundating the station, Priory Lower School and many houses. The Ouse is little used now, only for angling and pleasure boats from Lewes Rowing Club.It is full of odd craft in the annual May Raft Race. {Lewes Water Supply}is mostly groundwater pumped at Southover from the chalk to reservoirs, then flowing by gravity to users. It is very pure, needing no filtration. Malling uses river water from Barcombe Mills reservoir.{Lewes' sewage}goes to the l9th century works for sedimentation.
